slides.text: Now solve real problems with multiplication! '5 children each have 2 apples. How many apples total?' Draw it: 5 groups of 2. Skip count: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10. Write it: 5 x 2 = 10. '3 vases each hold 10 flowers. How many flowers?' 3 groups of 10: skip count 10, 20, 30. Write: 3 x 10 = 30. Multiplication helps us count QUICKLY and EFFICIENTLY!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun part: solving real-life puzzles with multiplication! If 5 friends each have 2 cookies, how many cookies are there altogether? We can draw 5 groups of 2, or skip count by 2 five times: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10. So, 5 x 2 = 10 cookies! Multiplication helps us count big groups super quickly.

slides.prompt:
1. Build these arrays with counters and write the multiplication sentence:
   - 2 rows of 5
   - 4 rows of 3
   - 5 rows of 10
   - 3 rows of 2
2. Draw arrays on graph paper for: 2x7, 5x4, 10x3. Write the product.
3. Solve: 6 spiders have 8 legs each — draw it, skip count it, write the multiplication.
4. Write each as repeated addition AND multiplication: 5+5+5 = ? x ? = ?
5. Start your multiplication progress chart: check off every fact you already know from skip counting!
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to build and draw! Grab your counters and make arrays for 2 rows of 5, then 4 rows of 3, and so on. After that, use your graph paper to draw arrays for 2x7, 5x4, and 10x3, and write down the total number, called the product. Then, let's tackle that spider problem – draw it, skip count it, and write the multiplication sentence. Finally, write out those addition problems as multiplication, and check off all the multiplication facts you already know on your progress chart!

slides.text: You have made the leap from skip counting to MULTIPLICATION. Every skip count you know is actually a multiplication table in disguise. 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 is really 2x1, 2x2, 2x3, 2x4, 2x5. You already know facts from the 2s, 5s, and 10s tables — that is a LOT of multiplication already mastered! In coming weeks, you will learn more tables and become multiplication experts.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain multiplication as counting equal groups? Can they build and interpret arrays? Can they connect skip counting to multiplication facts? Do they know the vocabulary: factors, product, times?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You've officially turned skip counting into multiplication! Every time you skip counted by 2s, 5s, or 10s, you were already mastering parts of multiplication. You know how to count equal groups and understand what arrays show. You're already a multiplication whiz with the 2s, 5s, and 10s!

parent_notes: This lesson formally introduces multiplication, but children have been building toward it all week through skip counting. The key insight: multiplication is not a new operation to fear — it is simply a faster way to count equal groups, something they have been doing naturally. Arrays are a powerful visual tool because they show multiplication as an organized picture. The connection between skip counting, arrays, repeated addition, and multiplication shows children that mathematics has MANY paths to the same answer. The progress chart is motivating — children are often surprised how many multiplication facts they already know. Do not rush toward memorization of tables; understanding the CONCEPT is far more important at this stage.

title: Ancient Mesopotamia — The Code of Hammurabi and Early Laws
description: Students learn about the world's first written law code, created by King Hammurabi of Babylon around 1754 BCE. They explore why societies need laws, how the Code of Hammurabi organized Babylonian society, and create their own classroom laws inspired by this ancient model.
instructions:
1. Review Mesopotamian civilization: cities, writing, wheel, irrigation.
2. Ask: When many people live together, what problems arise?
3. Introduce King Hammurabi of Babylon.
4. Explain: Hammurabi created 282 laws carved on a stone stele.
5. Read simplified examples of Hammurabi's laws.
6. Discuss: Are these laws fair? Would we change any?
7. Explain why written laws matter: everyone knows the rules.
8. Compare to modern laws: what is similar? What is different?
9. Students write their own 'class code' of 5-10 fair rules.
10. Place Hammurabi on the timeline: approximately 1754 BCE.
materials_needed: Clay or large paper (for students' law code)

slides.heading: The Code of Hammurabi
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book about an ancient king named Hammurabi. It tells us he created the very first set of written laws a super, super long time ago!

items: Simplified law cards from Hammurabi's Code
Clay slab or large paper for writing laws
slides.setup_instructions: Print an image of Hammurabi's stele (the black stone pillar with laws carved on it, now in the Louvre museum). Prepare simplified, age-appropriate versions of selected laws. Some laws involve harsh punishments — choose laws that illustrate fairness and social organization rather than violence.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these cool things we need for our project! We have a picture of that big stone pillar Hammurabi used, some cards with his old laws on them, and a special clay slab or big paper where we'll write our *own* rules, plus journals and markers to help us.

slides.text: Imagine a city with thousands of people: farmers, builders, merchants, priests. People argue. Someone steals a goat. A builder makes a house that collapses. A merchant cheats a customer. How do you keep ORDER? King HAMMURABI of Babylon had an answer: write down the rules so EVERYONE knows them. He created 282 laws, carved on a stone pillar for all to see. This was the world's first written LAW CODE.
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine a busy city with tons of people, right? Lots of things could go wrong, like someone taking something that isn't theirs or a building falling down! King Hammurabi wanted to make sure everyone knew the rules, so he wrote them all down on a giant stone pillar.

slides.text: Some of Hammurabi's laws: 'If a builder builds a house that collapses and kills the owner, the builder shall be put to death.' 'If a man borrows an ox and it dies, he must pay the owner.' 'If a doctor heals a broken bone, the patient shall pay five shekels of silver.' These laws covered everything: property, family, work, trade, and injury.
slides.mascot_explanation: These cards show some of the actual laws Hammurabi made! Like, if a builder made a house that fell down and hurt someone, the builder might be in big trouble. Other laws were about paying people back if something they borrowed got broken.

slides.text: Why were WRITTEN laws so important? Before Hammurabi, powerful people could make up rules on the spot. Written laws meant the rules were the SAME for everyone (in theory). You could look at the stone and KNOW what was expected. This is a foundational idea in civilization: the RULE OF LAW — written rules that apply to all people.
slides.mascot_explanation: Before Hammurabi wrote laws down, people might have just made up rules whenever they felt like it. But when rules are written on a stone for everyone to see, it means they're the same for everybody, and nobody can just change them on a whim!

slides.text: Were Hammurabi's laws perfect? No — they treated people differently based on social class, and some punishments were very harsh. But the IDEA was revolutionary: that society should be governed by clear, written rules rather than the whims of whoever was in power. This idea lives on in every constitution, every law book, and every set of community rules we have today.
slides.mascot_explanation: Hammurabi's laws weren't perfect – some punishments were super harsh, and they weren't always fair to everyone. But the big, important idea was that *written rules* were better than just having a leader decide things randomly.

slides.prompt:
1. Read the simplified law cards. For each, discuss: Is this law fair? Would you keep it, change it, or remove it?
2. Create your own 'CLASS CODE' — write 5-10 fair rules for your learning community. Each rule should:
   - Be clear (everyone understands it)
   - Be fair (applies to everyone equally)
   - Have a reasonable consequence
3. Write your Code on a large paper or clay slab (like Hammurabi's stele).
4. In your history journal: Why do communities need laws? What makes a law fair?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be like Hammurabi! We're going to read those law cards and decide if we think they're fair. Then, we'll create our *own* list of 5 to 10 rules for our classroom, making sure they're clear and fair for everyone.

slides.text: Hammurabi's Code was not just a list of laws — it was a revolutionary idea: that society should be organized by written rules, known to all, applied fairly. This idea is nearly 4,000 years old, and we still live by it today. Every time you see a sign with rules at a park, or hear about a new law being passed, remember: it all started with a king in Babylon who carved 282 laws on a stone pillar.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain who Hammurabi was and what his Code was? Can they describe why written laws were important? Can they discuss whether specific laws are fair? Can they create their own set of fair rules?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You thought about what makes rules fair and even created your own "Class Code," just like King Hammurabi did thousands of years ago. It's amazing how his idea of writing down rules still helps us stay organized today!

parent_notes: The Code of Hammurabi introduces children to the concept of rule of law, which is fundamental to civilization. The lesson naturally raises questions about fairness, justice, and the purpose of rules — rich discussions for the dinner table. Some of Hammurabi's laws involve harsh punishments (including death); the simplified versions should focus on laws about property, contracts, and social responsibility rather than violent penalties. The activity of writing their own rules is powerful because it puts children in the lawmaker's role — they must think about fairness, clarity, and consequences. Connect to modern rules they encounter: school rules, sports rules, traffic laws. The big idea: societies function better when everyone agrees on rules.

title: Matter Investigation — Classifying Materials and Their Properties
description: Students apply their knowledge of states of matter to classify everyday materials. They investigate properties like hardness, flexibility, transparency, and magnetism, and discover that understanding material properties helps us choose the right material for every job.
instructions:
1. Review: solid, liquid, gas — and how to identify each.
2. Introduce PROPERTIES: characteristics we can observe, measure, or test.
3. Property 1: Hardness — can you scratch it? (Mohs scale simplified).
4. Property 2: Flexibility — does it bend without breaking?
5. Property 3: Transparency — can you see through it?
6. Property 4: Magnetism — does a magnet attract it?
7. Set up a testing station with various materials.
8. Students test each material for all four properties.
9. Record results in a data table.
10. Discuss: Why do builders choose specific materials for specific jobs?
materials_needed: Various test materials (wood, metal, plastic, glass, rubber, fabric, paper, rock, aluminum foil)

slides.heading: Matter Investigation
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is the title of our whole adventure! It's called "Matter Investigation," and we're going to be like super detectives looking closely at different kinds of stuff, or "materials," to figure out what makes them special. We'll be testing their "properties," which are just the special things we can see or feel about them.

items: Test materials: wood block, metal spoon, plastic cup, glass jar, rubber band, fabric swatch, paper, small rock, aluminum foil
slides.setup_instructions: Set up a testing station with all materials laid out. Prepare a simple data table with material names in rows and properties (hardness, flexibility, transparency, magnetism) in columns. Children will test each material and record results. This is a genuine scientific investigation!
slides.mascot_explanation: Whoa, look at all these cool things! This slide shows us all the materials we'll need for our investigation. We've got things like a wood block, a metal spoon, a plastic cup, and even a rubber band and some fabric. We also have a special magnet and a flashlight, and our science journal to write everything down. Gather all these items so we're ready to become scientists!

slides.text: We know that all matter is either solid, liquid, or gas. But even within solids, materials are incredibly DIFFERENT. A diamond is the hardest substance on Earth, while chalk crumbles in your hand. Rubber bends, but glass shatters. You can see through water but not through milk. These differences are called PROPERTIES — the characteristics that make each material unique.
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how everything around us is either a solid, a liquid, or a gas? Well, even though many things are solids, they can be super different! This slide explains that "properties" are the special things that make each material unique, like how a diamond is super hard but chalk is soft and crumbles. These differences are what we'll be looking for today.

slides.text: Today we test four properties. HARDNESS: How resistant is the material to scratching? Try gently scratching each material with a coin — does it leave a mark? FLEXIBILITY: Can you bend the material without breaking it? A rubber band bends easily; a rock does not bend at all. Careful with glass — it is hard but NOT flexible!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we start testing! We're going to learn about four important properties. First is hardness – we'll see if we can scratch something, like trying to scratch a coin on a piece of wood. Then there's flexibility, which is all about if something can bend without snapping, like a rubber band versus a hard rock. Be careful with glass, it's hard but it won't bend!

slides.text: TRANSPARENCY: Can light pass through the material? Hold each material up to the flashlight. Glass is transparent (you can see through it clearly). Wax paper is TRANSLUCENT (some light gets through, but you cannot see clearly). Wood is OPAQUE (no light passes through). MAGNETISM: Does a magnet stick to the material? Test each one — you may be surprised!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to test for transparency and magnetism! Transparency means if we can see through something – we'll use our flashlight to check if light passes through. Some things are transparent like glass, some are translucent like wax paper where you can see a little, and some are opaque like wood where you can't see through at all. Then, we'll use our magnet to see what sticks – get ready for some surprises!

slides.text: Scientists and engineers choose materials based on their properties. A window must be transparent — so we use glass. A bridge must be strong — so we use steel. A raincoat must repel water — so we use waterproof fabric. Understanding properties helps us choose the RIGHT material for every job. What properties would you need for a cooking pot? A pillow? A bicycle tire?
slides.mascot_explanation: Why do we even care about all these properties? Well, this slide shows us that knowing a material's properties helps us pick the perfect thing for any job! Builders use strong steel for bridges because it's hard, and we use glass for windows because we can see through it. Think about what properties a pillow needs – probably soft and squishy!

slides.prompt:
Materials Investigation:
1. Set up your data table with columns: Material, Hard?, Flexible?, Transparent?, Magnetic?
2. Test each material for all four properties. Record YES or NO in each cell.
3. Which material is the hardest? The most flexible? The most transparent? The most magnetic?
4. Design challenge: What material would you choose for:
   - A window? (needs to be transparent)
   - A hammer? (needs to be hard)
   - A diving suit? (needs to be flexible and waterproof)
5. In your journal: 'Properties help us because...' Write 3 reasons.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, it's your turn to be the scientist! We're going to test each item we gathered and write down YES or NO for whether it's hard, flexible, transparent, or magnetic. Then, we'll figure out which material was the hardest, most flexible, most transparent, and most magnetic. After that, you'll get to choose materials for a window, a hammer, and a diving suit, and write down why properties are important!

slides.text: Every material in the world has a unique set of properties. By testing and understanding these properties, we can make smart choices about which material to use for any purpose. Scientists who study materials are called MATERIALS SCIENTISTS, and their work affects everything from the phone in your pocket to the rockets that fly to space. You conducted real scientific investigations today — testing, observing, and recording data. That IS science!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child test materials for hardness, flexibility, transparency, and magnetism? Can they record results in a data table? Can they explain why specific materials are chosen for specific purposes? Can they classify materials by their properties?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You acted like a real scientist today by testing all those materials and recording what you found. You learned that every single material has its own special properties, and knowing them helps us choose the best material for everything, from our phones to rockets! That's pretty amazing work!

parent_notes: This investigation lesson develops scientific process skills: observing, testing, recording data, and drawing conclusions. The data table is an important tool in science — filling one out teaches systematic recording. The magnetism test is often surprising: children expect all metals to be magnetic, but aluminum, copper, and gold are not. This leads to the insight that 'metal' is not one thing — different metals have different properties. The design challenge (choosing materials for specific purposes) connects science to engineering and everyday decision-making. Extend this at home by discussing the materials in your house: why are pipes made of copper? Why are windows made of glass? Why are tires made of rubber? Each answer connects to material properties.

title: Mixed Media Desert Landscape — Combining Art Techniques
description: Students create a mixed media desert landscape artwork, combining drawing, painting, and collage techniques. They apply their knowledge of the desert biome from geography and observation drawing skills from earlier in the week to create an expressive, layered desert scene.
instructions:
1. Review the desert biome: what does a desert landscape look like?
2. Show examples of desert art: Georgia O'Keeffe, David Hockney.
3. Plan the composition: foreground, middle ground, background.
4. Step 1: Paint the background (sky and distant mountains) with watercolors.
5. Step 2: Draw desert features (rock formations, sand dunes) with crayons or oil pastels.
6. Step 3: Collage elements — cut and glue textured paper for sand, cacti.
7. Step 4: Add details with fine markers or colored pencils.
8. Discuss warm color palette: oranges, reds, yellows, browns.
9. Add animals or plants from observation drawing practice.
10. Display and discuss finished artworks.
materials_needed: Textured paper for collage (sandpaper, tissue paper, construction paper)

slides.heading: Mixed Media Desert
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of a super cool art project! It tells us we're going to make a desert picture using lots of different art supplies all mixed together. It’s going to be a mixed media desert, which means we'll use more than one kind of art material to make it look awesome.

items: Textured papers: sandpaper, tissue paper, construction paper
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare the workspace for multiple media: painting area (with water cups and paper towels), drawing supplies, and collage station with pre-cut textured papers. Thick paper or cardstock is essential — it must hold watercolor paint without buckling. Have images of desert landscapes and desert art visible for reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these amazing art supplies! We have paint and brushes for colorful skies, crayons and pastels for drawing sandy hills, and special textured papers that feel like real sand or rocks. We’ll also need scissors and glue to stick everything down, and markers or colored pencils for tiny details, all on a sturdy piece of paper. Go grab everything you need, and let's get ready to create!

slides.text: This week we studied deserts in geography and observation drawing in art. Today we combine EVERYTHING into one amazing artwork: a mixed media desert landscape! MIXED MEDIA means using more than one art material — we will paint, draw, AND collage. Our desert will be LAYERED, just like real desert landscapes.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like our project's mission statement! It reminds us that we've learned about deserts and how to draw what we see, and now we get to put it all together. We'll use different art tools, like painting, drawing, and gluing, to build up our desert scene in layers, just like a real place.

slides.text: First, plan your COMPOSITION. The BACKGROUND is farthest away: the sky and distant mountains. The MIDDLE GROUND is in between: rock formations, mesas, sand dunes. The FOREGROUND is closest to you: cacti, rocks, desert flowers, maybe an animal. Deserts use WARM COLORS: oranges, reds, golds, browns, and the deep blue of a desert sky.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we become desert architects! We need to think about what's close to us, what's in the middle, and what's far away in our desert picture. The background is the sky and faraway mountains, the middle is things like rock formations, and the foreground is what's right up close, like cacti. Remember to use warm colors like oranges, reds, and yellows to make our desert feel sunny and hot!

slides.text: Start with watercolor for the BACKGROUND: wet your paper lightly, then brush warm sunset colors across the sky. While it dries, cut out collage shapes from textured paper: sandpaper makes excellent rocky ground, crumpled tissue paper makes great sand textures. These will go in the middle ground and foreground.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, time to get our hands a little wet with paint! We're going to paint the sky and the faraway mountains in the background with watercolors, making it look like a beautiful sunset. While that's drying, we can get a head start on the next part by cutting out different shapes from our textured papers – maybe some bumpy ones for rocks and some crinkly ones for sand.

slides.text: Once the background is dry, add crayons or oil pastels for rock formations and sand dunes. Glue your collage pieces into the middle ground and foreground. Finally, add fine details with markers or colored pencils: spines on a cactus, patterns on a lizard, cracks in rocks. Each LAYER of media adds depth and texture to your desert scene.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to add even more amazing details! After the paint is dry, we'll use crayons or oil pastels to draw sand dunes and rocky areas, and then we’ll glue down those cool textured paper shapes we cut out earlier. Finally, we’ll use fine markers or colored pencils to add tiny things like cactus needles or patterns on rocks, making each layer of our desert picture pop!

slides.prompt:
Create your mixed media desert landscape:
1. Paint the background sky and distant landscape with watercolors. Let it dry.
2. While waiting, cut collage shapes from textured paper: sandy ground, rock formations, cacti shapes.
3. Add crayon or oil pastel details: rock patterns, sand ripples, mesa outlines.
4. Glue collage elements into the middle ground and foreground.
5. Add fine details with markers: cactus spines, animal features, flower petals.
6. Sign your artwork and give it a title.
7. Write an artist's statement: 'My desert shows...' (2-3 sentences about your artistic choices).
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to make your very own desert masterpiece! First, paint your background sky and distant mountains with watercolors, then let it dry completely. While you wait, cut out some textured paper shapes for sand and cacti, and then use crayons or oil pastels to draw some rock formations. Once the paint is dry, glue down your collage pieces, add details with markers, and then sign your name and give your awesome desert a title!

slides.text: You created a desert landscape using FOUR different art techniques: watercolor painting, crayon drawing, paper collage, and marker details. Each technique adds something different: paint gives color and atmosphere, crayons give bold shapes, collage adds texture you can feel, and markers add fine details. This is what real artists do — they choose the RIGHT tool for each part of their vision. You are not just making art — you are thinking like an artist.
slides.mastery_check: Did the child use multiple media (paint, crayon, collage, marker)? Does the artwork show foreground, middle ground, and background? Did they use warm desert colors? Does the artwork reflect knowledge of the desert biome?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at that incredible desert you made! You used paint, crayons, textured paper, and markers – that's four different ways to make art, just like a real artist! You made sure to show things up close, in the middle, and far away, and used all those warm desert colors. You really thought about what a desert looks like and how to show it in your art!

parent_notes: Mixed media art encourages creative risk-taking and problem-solving. Children learn that different materials have different strengths: watercolor creates beautiful atmospheric backgrounds, collage adds tactile texture, and markers provide precise details. The layering process teaches patience — waiting for paint to dry before adding the next layer is a valuable exercise in delayed gratification. The cross-curricular connection (desert biome from geography) reinforces learning through a different modality. Georgia O'Keeffe's desert paintings are excellent references — her bold, simple compositions are accessible to children. The artist's statement at the end develops metacognitive awareness about artistic choices. Display the finished work prominently — art deserves an audience.
